item.title: Groundhog Day, 1993 - ★★★★★
item.description:
[recognizes Phil and runs up to him on the street]
Ned: Phil? Hey, Phil? Phil! Phil Connors? Phil Connors, I thought that was you!
[thinking Ned's just a watcher of the local news]
Phil: Hi, how you doing? Thanks for watching.
[Starts to walk away]

Ned: Hey, hey! Now, don't you tell me you don't remember me because I sure as heckfire remember you.
[bemused]
Phil: Not a chance.
Ned: Ned...
[takes off his hat revealing his completely bald head]

Ned: Ryerson. "Needlenose Ned"? "Ned the Head"? C'mon, buddy. Case Western High. Ned Ryerson: I did the whistling belly-button trick at the high school talent show? Bing! Ned Ryerson: got the shingles real bad senior year, almost didn't graduate? Bing, again. Ned Ryerson: I dated your sister Mary Pat a couple times until you told me not to anymore? Well?
[not even a smidgen of recognition]
Phil: Ned Ryerson?
Ned: Bing!
Phil: Bing. So did you turn pro with that bellybutton thing, Ned?
Ned: No, Phil, I sell insurance.
[deadpan]
Phil: What a shock.
Ned: Do you have life insurance? Because if you do you could always use a little more. Am I right or am I right or am I right? Right? Right?
[feigning politeness and failing]
Phil: Ned, I'd love to stand here and talk with you... but I'm not going to. See you.
[laughs]
Ned: That's okay! I'll walk with you!
[does so, to Phil's annoyance]

Ned: See, whenever I see an opportunity, I charge it like a bull. "Ned the Bull", that's me now. You know, I have friends who live and die by the actuarial tables and I say, "Hey! It's all one big crap-shoot anywho!" Tell me, have you ever heard of single premium life because I think that could really be the ticket for you.
[stops Phil in admiration]

Ned: Oh, God! It is so good to see you! Tell me, what are you doing for dinner?
Phil: Something else. It's been great seeing you, "Needlehead". Take care.
[Phil steps off the curb into a deep, watery puddle. Ned laughs obnoxiously]

Ned: Whoa-ho-ho! Watch out for that first step! It's a doozy!
[as Ned continues to cackle, Phil stomps away]

item.title: Wicked: For Good, 2025 - ★★★½
item.description:
why didn't anyone tell me these films are about fascism?

went in for sparkly musical numbers, got a masterclass in manufacturing enemies and consolidating power through propaganda. the Wizard isn't even subtle about it.

Glinda's entire arc is just: stay silent to stay safe → benefit from the system → realize you're complicit. Ariana Grande played "well-meaning liberal who enables fascism" so well it hurt.

Ariana Grande deserves everything.

really surprised that i enjoyed these so much, though maybe i shouldn't be since i loved The Wizard of Oz growing up. the music is pretty good, too!

item.title: 28 Years Later, 2025 - ★★★★
item.description:
can't believe i waited so long to watch this again but i'm glad i did so after experiencing The Bone Temple because this movie makes so much more sense now. once Kelson appears and begins to exposit, this slows down a good bit in contrast to the frenetic energy of the first half.

i kind of lost it when Kelson told Spike, "Find a place for her, the best one of all." great story, very much rewards a rewatch.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: 28 Years Later: The Bone Temple, 2026 - ★★★★★ (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

More movies should do what Luca Guadagnino did for CMBYN and save the title card for the end. I would have swapped up the sequence a bit, so the final shot of the bone temple is that aerial view, then TITLE CARD, and then it finishes off with the Jim cameo sequence and the setup for the final 28 Years entry

item.title: Call Me by Your Name, 2017 - ★★★★★
item.description:
I've decided I'm going to go see Marty Supreme when it plays at The Capri Theater and I wanted to remind myself of where Chalamet came from and how he entered my consciousness.

Despite knowing I've witnessed his appearance in Interstellar, I wasn't aware of him as an actor until his press tour leading up to the release of this film. There's so much he does here that is genuinely good, combined with lots of compelling score and scéne.

item.title: Pig, 2021 - ★★★★★
item.description:
It's been more than 2 years since I last saw this film.

I've finally got a couple black truffle dinners under my belt so I could finally understand Chef Finway and why "truffles are a key concept of the winter menu" and how that motivated him to do business with someone who would steal a pig.

I hope Derek did open that pub.

i think i expected a bit more out of Pattinson, but i also appreciate that his character wasn't what i expected.

4 stars for j law.
4 stars for the cloud shots (there are multiple, but a few took my breath away)

item.title: For All Mankind, 1989 - ★★★★★
item.description:
lifetime entry #1989

released the year of my birth, this film was a lovely meditation on human purpose and imagination. i loved every single one of these 80 miraculous minutes.

there is such depth and breadth allowed here. this made me feel like i was seeing into the inner workings of astronauts' minds while experiencing this monumental feat

item.title: Bear's November Movie Challenge
item.description:
Bear challenged me to list movies with a "November" vibe. Bear gave a subjective trifecta but I've forgotten it (please add it in a comment, thank you!)

My interpretation of these vibes led me to review my watchlist as well as my diary and I sought these qualities:
- Visual: muted/desaturated, bare trees, overcast skies, early darkness
- Emotional: contemplative melancholy, not depression exactly but... reckoning
- Narrative: moral ambiguity, isolation, characters alone with consequences
- Pacing: patient, meditative, space to think

Did I succeed?

  • Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
  • Manchester by the Sea
  • The Wind Will Carry Us
  • Fargo
  • Mulholland Drive
  • In Bruges
  • The Witch
  • A Serious Man
  • First Reformed
  • A Ghost Story

...plus 4 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC: Jake Sullivan’s Top 20
item.description:
• Cool Hand Luke

    A crash course in humanity. 

    "No man can eat 50 eggs."

  • The Godfather

    A crash course in film. Perfect in every aspect.

  • Blood Simple

    #3 is a revolving door of Coen films. This spot belongs to whichever I'm feeling the most on a given day. Their debut is underappreciated and seems like an appropriate placeholder.

  • Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid

    Every top 20 should have a western. And the best westerns are about bucking authority and beating the odds.

  • The Truman Show

    My life is definitely not filled by paid actors. But my brain thinks it might be.

  • Big Night

    The movie that taught me to appreciate food. And business. And Louie Prima.

    "Bite your teeth into the ass of life."

  • White Men Can't Jump

    Iconic 90s.

  • Thicker Than Water

    When I am wistful, surf docs settle my soul. This one is my go to.

  • Good Will Hunting

    Robin Williams at his very best and most vulnerable. RIP.

  • Attack the Block

    Pure fun. Easily my favorite monster movie.

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC: Jonathan Miles’ Top 20 Films
item.description:
Classics, action, comedy, fantasy. This list has a little of everything.

  1. The Big Lebowski

    The greatest film ever made, bar none. Shut the fuck up, Donny

  2. The Nice Guys

    Just two guys, in way over their heads.

  3. There Will Be Blood

    One of the greatest Method acting performances of all time, although my contention will ever be that Daniel Day-Lewis deserved his second Oscar before this for Gangs of New York.

  4. Hell or High Water

    The best Texas noir film since No Country For Old Men.

  5. Pride & Prejudice

    A stirringly scored, beautifully shot adaptation of the Austen novel.

  6. The Searchers

    A visually brilliant, brutally spectacular film, and the performance that should have won John Wayne his Academy Award, for bitter, racist ex-Confederate Ethan Edwards.

  7. Zodiac

    David Fincher’s masterpiece. A stacked cast and a case that was never solved.

  8. When Harry Met Sally...

    The ultimate rom-com

  9. Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby

    If you eat the DVD, it tastes like America

  10. Silver Linings Playbook

    Go Birds

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC: Quentin Jones' Top 20
item.description:
Quentin Jones, friend of the film club, listed his top 20 on the most recent episode of Jackson Film Club The Podcast.

Quentin found himself in Jackson after working on the film crew for the episode of We Are Here created in Jackson in 2022. His first and foremost reason for his residence in the city is the love of his life, Lydia. His second reason is his mission for cannabis awareness and advancement in the state's new medical marijuana program. His third reason is the great dance floor at Shade.

This top 20 list features epic American classics and some of the most innovative and groundbreaking cinema in the world. Tune in to our conversation wherever you get your podcasts.

Though this is presented as a ranked list, the films in positions 22 - 24 are honorable mentions and despicable artists-now-canceled.

  1. Get Out
  2. The Big Lebowski
  3. In the Mood for Love
  4. Hairspray
  5. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
  6. Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
  7. Blue Velvet
  8. Do the Right Thing
  9. Moonlight
  10. Barbie

...plus 14 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: JXNFC - Animated Features
item.description:
This list was the basis of a special podcast episode. Check the link for more

https://jxnfilm.club/#animated-features

  • The Land Before Time

    Entered by Michael

    This film is my waypoint for consciousness -- I came to an understanding of death emotionally because of this movie. Nothing has ever quite hit the same, to be honest.

  • Rock-A-Doodle

    Entered by Michael

    When my parents would go to their weekly bowling league, I was the kid who would change the TV to Rock-A-Doodle at the childcare center next door.

  • One Hundred and One Dalmatians

    Entered by Michael

  • Princess Mononoke

    Entered by Michael

    This was when I realized that animation is for grownups, and that grownup stories can be told through animation. I love how this changed my imagination.

  • Spirited Away

    Entered by Michael

    I found this not far from the age of Chihiro. It means a lot to me because I moved twice before the age of 10 and this film teaches about life in its own way, through the eyes of a young person who has been Spirited Away.

  • Samurai Champloo

    Entered by Michael

    This anime popped up on Adult Swim, but I never finished the series on the air. Nearly 20 years later, I've finally watched the entirety and absolutely loved the ending.

  • The Hobbit

    Entered by Morgan

  • Heavy Metal

    Entered by Morgan

  • Waking Life

    Entered by Morgan

  • The Secret of Kells

    Entered by Morgan

...plus 1 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: 2022 Goal: 100 New Directors
item.description:
I started the year with a pretty interesting ratio of 1.28:1 for number of films by a director. On 14 October 2021 I reached a milestone of 500 directors from 646 logged films, spanning 41 countries, inspiring my 2022 goal of watching 100 movies introducing myself to that many more new directors. As of completion of this goal, my ratio is 1.33 movies per director with over 700 directors logged. I look forward to seeing where it's at when I hit 1500 movies logged

tl;dr: for every movie on this list, 2022 is the first time I’ve seen something from that director.

  1. The Hand of God
  2. The Lost Daughter
  3. Summer of Soul (...Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised)
  4. The Mask of Zorro
  5. The Paradise Next Door
  6. Lunch on the Grass
  7. Doctor Strange
  8. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
  9. A Bridge Too Far
  10. Encanto

...plus 89 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
